@graph.reasoning: None of our cases disputes that proposition.

@graph.@id: Utah Pie Co. v. Continental Baking Co.
@graph.involvedParties: Utah Pie Co. v. Continental Baking Co.
@graph.reasoning: Threat to competition may be shown by predatory intent, combined with injury to competitor.

@graph.@id: Lomar Wholesale Grocery, Inc. v. Dieter's Gourmet Foods, Inc.
@graph.involvedParties: Lomar Wholesale Grocery, Inc. v. Dieter's Gourmet Foods, Inc.
@graph.reasoning: Threat to competition may be shown by predatory intent, combined with injury to competitor.

@graph.@id: Double H Plastics, Inc. v. Sonoco Products Co.
@graph.involvedParties: Double H Plastics, Inc. v. Sonoco Products Co.
@graph.reasoning: Threat to competition may be shown by evidence of predatory intent, in form of below-cost pricing.

@graph.@id: D. E. Rogers Associates, Inc. v. Gardner-Denver Co.
@graph.involvedParties: D. E. Rogers Associates, Inc. v. Gardner-Denver Co.
@graph.reasoning: Anticompetitive effect may be proven inferentially from anticompetitive intent.

@graph.@id: Board of Trade of Chicago v. United States
@graph.involvedParties: Board of Trade of Chicago v. United States
@graph.reasoning: In determining whether rule violates antitrust law, knowledge of intent may help the court to interpret facts and to predict consequences.
Lawyers know less about the business than the people they represent; judges know even less about the business than the lawyers.

@graph.@id: BROOKE GROUP LTD. v. BROWN & WILLIAMSON TOBACCO CORP.
@graph.reasoning: The jury was entitled to infer that B&W's below-cost pricing actually produced supracompetitive prices, with the help of tacit collusion among the players.
